outcomes.title: Average vs Instantaneous Rates of Change
outcomes.description: Determine the average rate of change of a function on an interval, and estimate the instantaneous rate of change of a function at a point.

exercises.pretext:
You may use a calculator.

  1. An exploration bot on the surface of the moon throws a stone off a cliff. The stone's height in meters above the surface after t seconds is given by s(t) = -0.81 \, t^{2} + 28 \, t + 99. What is the average rate of change of the height of the stone with respect to time on the interval [13.5,32.1]? Round to 3 decimal places and include the correct units.
  2. Estimate numerically the slope of the tangent line to the given function at the given point. Round your answer to 3 decimal places. f(y)=4 \, y^{2} + 9 \, y - 7, \;a=-0.5
  1. -8.936\;\mathrm{m/s}
  2. 5.0
exercises.html:
You may use a calculator.

  1. An exploration bot on the surface of the moon throws a stone off a cliff. The stone's height in meters above the surface after \(t\) seconds is given by

    \[s(t) = -0.81 \, t^{2} + 28 \, t + 99.\]

    What is the average rate of change of the height of the stone with respect to time on the interval \([13.5,32.1]\)? Round to 3 decimal places and include the correct units.
  2. Estimate numerically the slope of the tangent line to the given function at the given point. Round your answer to 3 decimal places.

    \[f(y)=4 \, y^{2} + 9 \, y - 7, \;a=-0.5\]

Answer:

  1. \(-8.936\;\mathrm{m/s}\)
  2. \(5.0\)

exercises.pretext:
You may use a calculator.

  1. An exploration bot on the surface of Uranus throws a rock off a cliff. The rock's height in meters above the surface after t seconds is given by s(t) = -4.435 \, t^{2} + 20 \, t + 52. What is the average rate of change of the height of the rock with respect to time on the interval [0.5,4.9]? Round to 3 decimal places and include the correct units.
  2. Estimate numerically the slope of the tangent line to the given function at the given point. Round your answer to 3 decimal places. g(t)=\sqrt{-5 \, t + 4}, \;a=-1
  1. -3.949\;\mathrm{m/s}
  2. -0.833

  1. An interplantary explorer on the surface of the distant planet Trone RM38 throws a rock off a cliff. The rock's height in meters above the surface after \(t\) seconds is given by

    \[s(t) = -5.93 \, t^{2} + 18 \, t + 66.\]

    What is the average rate of change of the height of the rock with respect to time on the interval \([1.5,2.9]\)? Round to 3 decimal places and include the correct units.
  2. Estimate numerically the slope of the tangent line to the given function at the given point. Round your answer to 3 decimal places.

    \[f(w)=\cos\left(w\right), \;a=\frac{8}{11} \, \pi\]

Answer:

  1. \(-8.092\;\mathrm{m/s}\)
  2. \(-0.756\)

  2. Estimate numerically the slope of the tangent line to the given function at the given point. Round your answer to 3 decimal places. g(w)=\sqrt{-8 \, w - 4}, \;a=-3

  2. -0.894

outcomes.title: Graphical Approach to Limits
outcomes.description: Evaluate limits (and one-sided) limits graphically. When limits are infinite, determine if they are infinity or negative infinity.

exercises.pretext:
Sketch the graph of a function f(x) that meets all of the following criteria. Be sure to scale your axes and label any important features of your graph.

  1. f(x) has a vertical asymptote at 9, but \lim_{x\to 9^+} f(x) is finite.

  2. \lim_{x\to 8} f(x)=-4, but f(8)=3.

  3. \lim_{x\to 6^+} f(x)=1 but \lim_{x\to 6^-} f(x)\neq1.

Answers vary. Here are some things to check for:

  • Does your graph represent a function? If your graph fails the vertical line test, it is not a function. This means there are two or more points on the graph that share the same x-value, which is not allowed!

  1. The graph should have a vertical asymptote at x=9. As the function approaches the vertical asymptote from the left, the function outputs should grow infinitely large in magnitude (either in the postive or negative y-direction). As the function approaches the vertical asymptote from the right, the function should bump straight into the vertical asymptote.

  2. The graph should approach the point (8,-4), but there should be a removable discontinuity (hole) in the graph right at that point (indicated by an open circle). The actual value of the function at x=8 should be 3, so the point (8,3) should be included on the graph.

  3. There is a jump or infinite discontinuity at x=6, but the function approaches the point (6,1) as x approaches 6 from the right.
exercises.html:
Sketch the graph of a function \(f(x)\) that meets all of the following criteria. Be sure to scale your axes and label any important features of your graph.

  1. \(f(x)\) has a vertical asymptote at \(9\), but \(\lim_{x\to 9^+} f(x)\) is finite.

  2. \(\lim_{x\to 8} f(x)=-4\), but \(f(8)=3\).

  3. \(\lim_{x\to 6^+} f(x)=1\) but \(\lim_{x\to 6^-} f(x)\neq1\).

Answer:

Answers vary. Here are some things to check for:

  • Does your graph represent a function? If your graph fails the vertical line test, it is not a function. This means there are two or more points on the graph that share the same \(x\)-value, which is not allowed!

  1. The graph should have a vertical asymptote at \(x=9\). As the function approaches the vertical asymptote from the left, the function outputs should grow infinitely large in magnitude (either in the postive or negative \(y\)-direction). As the function approaches the vertical asymptote from the right, the function should bump straight into the vertical asymptote.

  2. The graph should approach the point \((8,-4)\), but there should be a removable discontinuity (hole) in the graph right at that point (indicated by an open circle). The actual value of the function at \(x=8\) should be \(3\), so the point \((8,3)\) should be included on the graph.

  3. There is a jump or infinite discontinuity at \(x=6\), but the function approaches the point \((6,1)\) as \(x\) approaches \(6\) from the right.

exercises.pretext:
Sketch the graph of a function g(x) that meets all of the following criteria. Be sure to scale your axes and label any important features of your graph.

  1. \lim_{x\to 0^-} g(x) and \lim_{x\to 0^+} g(x) are both infinite.

  2. \lim_{x\to 3} g(x)=-4, but g(3)=-1.

  3. \lim_{x\to 1^-} g(x)=1 and \lim_{x\to 1^+} g(x)=3.

Answers vary. Here are some things to check for:

  • Does your graph represent a function? If your graph fails the vertical line test, it is not a function. This means there are two or more points on the graph that share the same x-value, which is not allowed!

  1. The graph should have a vertical asymptote at x=0. The function should grow in magnitude as it approaches the vertical asymptote from both the left and right.

  2. The graph should approach the point (3,-4), but there should be a removable discontinuity (hole) in the graph right at that point (indicated by an open circle). The actual value of the function at x=3 should be -1, so the point (3,-1) should be included on the graph.

  3. There is a jump discontinuity at x=1 with the graph approaching the point (1,1) as x approaches 1 from the left and approaching the point (1,3) as x approaches 1 from the right.
exercises.html:
Sketch the graph of a function \(g(x)\) that meets all of the following criteria. Be sure to scale your axes and label any important features of your graph.

  1. \(\lim_{x\to 0^-} g(x)\) and \(\lim_{x\to 0^+} g(x)\) are both infinite.

  2. \(\lim_{x\to 3} g(x)=-4\), but \(g(3)=-1\).

  3. \(\lim_{x\to 1^-} g(x)=1\) and \(\lim_{x\to 1^+} g(x)=3\).

Answer:

Answers vary. Here are some things to check for:

  • Does your graph represent a function? If your graph fails the vertical line test, it is not a function. This means there are two or more points on the graph that share the same \(x\)-value, which is not allowed!

  1. The graph should have a vertical asymptote at \(x=0\). The function should grow in magnitude as it approaches the vertical asymptote from both the left and right.

  2. The graph should approach the point \((3,-4)\), but there should be a removable discontinuity (hole) in the graph right at that point (indicated by an open circle). The actual value of the function at \(x=3\) should be \(-1\), so the point \((3,-1)\) should be included on the graph.

  3. There is a jump discontinuity at \(x=1\) with the graph approaching the point \((1,1)\) as \(x\) approaches \(1\) from the left and approaching the point \((1,3)\) as \(x\) approaches \(1\) from the right.

exercises.pretext:
Sketch the graph of a function h(x) that meets all of the following criteria. Be sure to scale your axes and label any important features of your graph.

  1. \lim_{x\to 2^-} h(x) and \lim_{x\to 2^+} h(x) are both infinite.

  2. \lim_{x\to 3} h(x) exists and h(3) is defined, but \lim_{x\to 3} h(x)\neq h(3).

  3. \lim_{x\to -3^-} h(x)\neq\lim_{x\to -3^+} h(x).

Answers vary. Here are some things to check for:

  • Does your graph represent a function? If your graph fails the vertical line test, it is not a function. This means there are two or more points on the graph that share the same x-value, which is not allowed!

  1. The graph should have a vertical asymptote at x=2. The function should grow in magnitude as it approaches the vertical asymptote from both the left and right.

  2. There should be a removable discontinuity (hole) on the graph at x=3 (indicated by an open circle on the graph at this point). The function should, however, be defined at x=3, so a point should appear on the graph at x=3 above or below the hole in the graph.

  3. There should be one of two things occuring at x=-3:

    • The graph has a jump discontinuity at x=-3, or...
    • The graph has a vertical asymptote at x=-3 with distinct function behaviors as the graph approaches the asymptote from the left versus from the right.
exercises.html:
Sketch the graph of a function \(h(x)\) that meets all of the following criteria. Be sure to scale your axes and label any important features of your graph.

  1. \(\lim_{x\to 2^-} h(x)\) and \(\lim_{x\to 2^+} h(x)\) are both infinite.

  2. \(\lim_{x\to 3} h(x)\) exists and \(h(3)\) is defined, but \(\lim_{x\to 3} h(x)\neq h(3)\).

  3. \(\lim_{x\to -3^-} h(x)\neq\lim_{x\to -3^+} h(x)\).

Answer:

Answers vary. Here are some things to check for:

  • Does your graph represent a function? If your graph fails the vertical line test, it is not a function. This means there are two or more points on the graph that share the same \(x\)-value, which is not allowed!

  1. The graph should have a vertical asymptote at \(x=2\). The function should grow in magnitude as it approaches the vertical asymptote from both the left and right.

  2. There should be a removable discontinuity (hole) on the graph at \(x=3\) (indicated by an open circle on the graph at this point). The function should, however, be defined at \(x=3\), so a point should appear on the graph at \(x=3\) above or below the hole in the graph.

  3. There should be one of two things occuring at \(x=-3:\)

    • The graph has a jump discontinuity at \(x=-3\), or...
    • The graph has a vertical asymptote at \(x=-3\) with distinct function behaviors as the graph approaches the asymptote from the left versus from the right.

exercises.pretext:
Sketch the graph of a function g(x) that meets all of the following criteria. Be sure to scale your axes and label any important features of your graph.

  1. \lim_{x\to 0^-} g(x) is finite, but \lim_{x\to 0^+} g(x) is infinite.

  2. \lim_{x\to 1} g(x)=-1, but g(1)=3.

  3. \lim_{x\to -1^-} g(x)=1 and \lim_{x\to -1^+} g(x)=-4.

Answers vary. Here are some things to check for:

  • Does your graph represent a function? If your graph fails the vertical line test, it is not a function. This means there are two or more points on the graph that share the same x-value, which is not allowed!

  1. The graph should have a vertical asymptote at x=0. As the function approaches the vertical asymptote from the left, the function should bump straight into the vertical asymptote. As the function approaches the vertical asymptote from the right, the function outputs should grow infinitely large in magnitude (either in the postive or negative y-direction).

  2. The graph should approach the point (1,-1), but there should be a removable discontinuity (hole) in the graph right at that point (indicated by an open circle). The actual value of the function at x=1 should be 3, so the point (1,3) should be included on the graph.

  3. There is a jump discontinuity at x=-1 with the graph approaching the point (-1,1) as x approaches -1 from the left and approaching the point (-1,-4) as x approaches -1 from the right.

As the function approaches the vertical asymptote from the right, the function outputs should grow infinitely large in magnitude (either in the postive or negative \(y\)-direction).

  3. There is a jump discontinuity at \(x=-1\) with the graph approaching the point \((-1,1)\) as \(x\) approaches \(-1\) from the left and approaching the point \((-1,-4)\) as \(x\) approaches \(-1\) from the right.

exercises.pretext:
Sketch the graph of a function h(x) that meets all of the following criteria. Be sure to scale your axes and label any important features of your graph.

  1. \lim_{x\to 1^-} h(x) is finite, but \lim_{x\to 1^+} h(x) is infinite.

  2. \lim_{x\to -3} h(x) exists and h(-3) is defined, but \lim_{x\to -3} h(x)\neq h(-3).

  3. \lim_{x\to -1^-} h(x)=4 and \lim_{x\to -1^+} h(x)=3.

Answers vary. Here are some things to check for:

  • Does your graph represent a function? If your graph fails the vertical line test, it is not a function. This means there are two or more points on the graph that share the same x-value, which is not allowed!

  1. The graph should have a vertical asymptote at x=1. As the function approaches the vertical asymptote from the left, the function should bump straight into the vertical asymptote. As the function approaches the vertical asymptote from the right, the function outputs should grow infinitely large in magnitude (either in the postive or negative y-direction).

  2. There should be a removable discontinuity (hole) on the graph at x=-3 (indicated by an open circle on the graph at this point). The function should, however, be defined at x=-3, so a point should appear on the graph at x=-3 above or below the hole in the graph.

  3. There is a jump discontinuity at x=-1 with the graph approaching the point (-1,4) as x approaches -1 from the left and approaching the point (-1,3) as x approaches -1 from the right.
exercises.html:
Sketch the graph of a function \(h(x)\) that meets all of the following criteria. Be sure to scale your axes and label any important features of your graph.

  1. \(\lim_{x\to 1^-} h(x)\) is finite, but \(\lim_{x\to 1^+} h(x)\) is infinite.

  2. \(\lim_{x\to -3} h(x)\) exists and \(h(-3)\) is defined, but \(\lim_{x\to -3} h(x)\neq h(-3)\).

  3. \(\lim_{x\to -1^-} h(x)=4\) and \(\lim_{x\to -1^+} h(x)=3\).

Answer:

Answers vary. Here are some things to check for:

  • Does your graph represent a function? If your graph fails the vertical line test, it is not a function. This means there are two or more points on the graph that share the same \(x\)-value, which is not allowed!

  1. The graph should have a vertical asymptote at \(x=1\). As the function approaches the vertical asymptote from the left, the function should bump straight into the vertical asymptote. As the function approaches the vertical asymptote from the right, the function outputs should grow infinitely large in magnitude (either in the postive or negative \(y\)-direction).

  2. There should be a removable discontinuity (hole) on the graph at \(x=-3\) (indicated by an open circle on the graph at this point). The function should, however, be defined at \(x=-3\), so a point should appear on the graph at \(x=-3\) above or below the hole in the graph.

  3. There is a jump discontinuity at \(x=-1\) with the graph approaching the point \((-1,4)\) as \(x\) approaches \(-1\) from the left and approaching the point \((-1,3)\) as \(x\) approaches \(-1\) from the right.

exercises.pretext:
Sketch the graph of a function f(x) that meets all of the following criteria. Be sure to scale your axes and label any important features of your graph.

  1. \lim_{x\to 3^-} f(x) is finite, but \lim_{x\to 3^+} f(x) is infinite.

  2. \lim_{x\to -2} f(x)=-1, but f(-2)=4.

  3. \lim_{x\to 1^+} f(x)=-4 but \lim_{x\to 1^-} f(x)\neq-4.

Answers vary. Here are some things to check for:

  • Does your graph represent a function? If your graph fails the vertical line test, it is not a function. This means there are two or more points on the graph that share the same x-value, which is not allowed!

  1. The graph should have a vertical asymptote at x=3. As the function approaches the vertical asymptote from the left, the function should bump straight into the vertical asymptote. As the function approaches the vertical asymptote from the right, the function outputs should grow infinitely large in magnitude (either in the postive or negative y-direction).

  2. The graph should approach the point (-2,-1), but there should be a removable discontinuity (hole) in the graph right at that point (indicated by an open circle). The actual value of the function at x=-2 should be 4, so the point (-2,4) should be included on the graph.

  3. There is a jump or infinite discontinuity at x=1, but the function approaches the point (1,-4) as x approaches 1 from the right.

exercises.pretext:
Sketch the graph of a function h(x) that meets all of the following criteria. Be sure to scale your axes and label any important features of your graph.

  1. h(x) has a vertical asymptote at -5, but \lim_{x\to -5^+} h(x) is finite.

  2. \lim_{x\to -2} h(x)=1, but h(-2)=3.

  3. \lim_{x\to -3^-} h(x)\neq\lim_{x\to -3^+} h(x).

Answers vary. Here are some things to check for:

  • Does your graph represent a function? If your graph fails the vertical line test, it is not a function. This means there are two or more points on the graph that share the same x-value, which is not allowed!

  1. The graph should have a vertical asymptote at x=-5. As the function approaches the vertical asymptote from the left, the function outputs should grow infinitely large in magnitude (either in the postive or negative y-direction). As the function approaches the vertical asymptote from the right, the function should bump straight into the vertical asymptote.

  2. The graph should approach the point (-2,1), but there should be a removable discontinuity (hole) in the graph right at that point (indicated by an open circle). The actual value of the function at x=-2 should be 3, so the point (-2,3) should be included on the graph.

  3. There should be one of two things occuring at x=-3:

    • The graph has a jump discontinuity at x=-3, or...
    • The graph has a vertical asymptote at x=-3 with distinct function behaviors as the graph approaches the asymptote from the left versus from the right.

outcomes.title: Continuity
outcomes.description: Determine where a function is continuous using the limit definition of continuity. If a function is not continuous at a particular value, classify the type of discontinuity, and determine if it is left- or right-continuous. Determine the value of a parameter to make a function continuous at a point. Explain why continuity is essential in the context of applying the Intermediate Value Theorem.

exercises.pretext:
1. Determine the value of b to make g(x) continuous at x=-3.

    g(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{b x^{2} - b x + 6 \, x - 6}{x + 6}, & x < -3 \\ 2 \, x + 8, & x \geq -3 \end{cases}

  2. The function h(x) is discontinuous at x=-3. Determine if h(x) is left- or right-continuous and classify the type of discontinuity present at x=-3.

    h(x) = \begin{cases} -\frac{5}{2} \, x - \frac{17}{2}, & x < -3 \\ \frac{x^{2} + 6 \, x + 8}{x + 5}, & x \geq -3 \end{cases}

  3. Sketch the graph of a function f(x) that satisfies both the assumptions and conclusion of the Intermediate Value Theorem on the interval [5,9] using the intermediate output value M=4 (between f(5) and f(9)). Explain why the assumptions of the IVT are important in this context.
  1. To make g(x) continuous at x=-3, let b=\frac{5}{2}.
  2. The function h(x) has a jump discontinuity and is right-continuous at x=-3.

  3. The function f(x) should be continuous on the interval [5,9]. There should be a point on the graph with the output value y=4.
exercises.html:
1. Determine the value of \(b\) to make \(g(x)\) continuous at \(x=-3\).

    \[ g(x) = \begin{cases} \frac{b x^{2} - b x + 6 \, x - 6}{x + 6}, & x < -3 \\ 2 \, x + 8, & x \geq -3 \end{cases} \]

  2. The function \(h(x)\) is discontinuous at \(x=-3\). Determine if \(h(x)\) is left- or right-continuous and classify the type of discontinuity present at \(x=-3\).

    \[ h(x) = \begin{cases} -\frac{5}{2} \, x - \frac{17}{2}, & x < -3 \\ \frac{x^{2} + 6 \, x + 8}{x + 5}, & x \geq -3 \end{cases} \]

  3. Sketch the graph of a function \(f(x)\) that satisfies both the assumptions and conclusion of the Intermediate Value Theorem on the interval \([5,9]\) using the intermediate output value \(M=4\) (between \(f(5)\) and \(f(9)\)). Explain why the assumptions of the IVT are important in this context.

Answer:

  1. To make \(g(x)\) continuous at \(x=-3\), let \(b=\frac{5}{2}\).
  2. The function \(h(x)\) has a jump discontinuity and is right-continuous at \(x=-3\).

  3. The function \(f(x)\) should be continuous on the interval \([5,9]\). There should be a point on the graph with the output value \(y=4\).

  2. The function g(x) is discontinuous at x=4. Determine if g(x) is left- or right-continuous and classify the type of discontinuity present at x=4.

    g(x) = \begin{cases} -x + 10, & x < 4 \\ \frac{x^{2} - 4 \, x + 4}{x - 1}, & x \geq 4 \end{cases}

  3. Sketch the graph of a function h(x) that satisfies both the assumptions and conclusion of the Intermediate Value Theorem on the interval [3,5] using the intermediate output value M=5 (between h(3) and h(5)). Explain why the assumptions of the IVT are important in this context.
  1. To make f(x) continuous at x=2, let b=\frac{3}{2}.
  2. The function g(x) has a jump discontinuity and is right-continuous at x=4.

  3. The function h(x) should be continuous on the interval [3,5]. There should be a point on the graph with the output value y=5.

exercises.pretext:
1. Determine the value of b to make g(x) continuous at x=5.

    g(x) = \begin{cases} b x - 3 \, x^{2} - 4, & x < 5 \\ 4 \, x - 20, & x \geq 5 \end{cases}

  2. The function f(x) is discontinuous at x=2. Determine if f(x) is left- or right-continuous and classify the type of discontinuity present at x=2.

    f(x) = \begin{cases} 4 \, x - 5, & x < 2 \\ \frac{x^{2} - 3 \, x - 18}{x^{2} - 2 \, x}, & x \geq 2 \end{cases}

  3. Sketch the graph of a function h(x) that does not satisfy the conclusion of the Intermediate Value Theorem on the interval [5,9] using the intermediate output value M=-1 (between h(5) and h(9)). Explain why, in general, the assumptions of the IVT are important.
  1. To make g(x) continuous at x=5, let b=\frac{79}{5}.
  2. The function f(x) has a infinite discontinuity and is neither left- nor right-continuous at x=2.

  3. The function h(x) should be discontinuous on the interval [5,9]. There should be no point on the graph with the output value y=-1.
exercises.html:
1. Determine the value of \(b\) to make \(g(x)\) continuous at \(x=5\).

    \[ g(x) = \begin{cases} b x - 3 \, x^{2} - 4, & x < 5 \\ 4 \, x - 20, & x \geq 5 \end{cases} \]

  2. The function \(f(x)\) is discontinuous at \(x=2\). Determine if \(f(x)\) is left- or right-continuous and classify the type of discontinuity present at \(x=2\).

    \[ f(x) = \begin{cases} 4 \, x - 5, & x < 2 \\ \frac{x^{2} - 3 \, x - 18}{x^{2} - 2 \, x}, & x \geq 2 \end{cases} \]

  3. Sketch the graph of a function \(h(x)\) that does not satisfy the conclusion of the Intermediate Value Theorem on the interval \([5,9]\) using the intermediate output value \(M=-1\) (between \(h(5)\) and \(h(9)\)). Explain why, in general, the assumptions of the IVT are important.

Answer:

  1. To make \(g(x)\) continuous at \(x=5\), let \(b=\frac{79}{5}\).
  2. The function \(f(x)\) has a infinite discontinuity and is neither left- nor right-continuous at \(x=2\).

  3. The function \(h(x)\) should be discontinuous on the interval \([5,9]\). There should be no point on the graph with the output value \(y=-1\).

exercises.pretext:
1. Determine the value of b to make h(x) continuous at x=-3.

    h(x) = \begin{cases} b - 9 \, x, & x \leq -3 \\ -x^{2} - 5 \, x - 9, & x > -3 \end{cases}

  2. The function f(x) is discontinuous at x=4. Determine if f(x) is left- or right-continuous and classify the type of discontinuity present at x=4.

    f(x) = \begin{cases} -\frac{3}{2} \, x + 10, & x \leq 4 \\ \frac{x^{2} - 9 \, x + 14}{x + 1}, & x > 4 \end{cases}

  3. Sketch the graph of a function g(x) that does not satisfy the conclusion of the Intermediate Value Theorem on the interval [1,6] using the intermediate output value M=-4 (between g(1) and g(6)). Explain why, in general, the assumptions of the IVT are important.
  1. To make h(x) continuous at x=-3, let b=-30.
  2. The function f(x) has a jump discontinuity and is left-continuous at x=4.

  3. The function g(x) should be discontinuous on the interval [1,6]. There should be no point on the graph with the output value y=-4.

exercises.pretext:
1. Determine the value of b to make f(x) continuous at x=5.

    f(x) = \begin{cases} b x + 4 \, x^{2} - \frac{4}{3}, & x \leq 5 \\ 3 \, x - 15, & x > 5 \end{cases}

  2. The function h(x) is discontinuous at x=2. Determine if h(x) is left- or right-continuous and classify the type of discontinuity present at x=2.

    h(x) = \begin{cases} -x + 5, & x \leq 2 \\ \frac{x^{2} - 7 \, x + 10}{x^{2} - 5 \, x + 6}, & x > 2 \end{cases}

  3. Sketch the graph of a function g(x) that does not satisfy the conclusion of the Intermediate Value Theorem on the interval [4,7] using the intermediate output value M=-2 (between g(4) and g(7)). Explain why, in general, the assumptions of the IVT are important.
  1. To make f(x) continuous at x=5, let b=-\frac{296}{15}.
  2. The function h(x) has a removable discontinuity and is left-continuous at x=2.

  3. The function g(x) should be discontinuous on the interval [4,7]. There should be no point on the graph with the output value y=-2.

exercises.pretext:
1. Determine the value of b to make f(x) continuous at x=-2.

    f(x) = \begin{cases} b x^{2} - x - 2, & x < -2 \\ x^{2}, & x \geq -2 \end{cases}

  2. The function h(x) is discontinuous at x=3. Determine if h(x) is left- or right-continuous and classify the type of discontinuity present at x=3.

    h(x) = \begin{cases} -4 \, x + 10, & x \leq 3 \\ \frac{x^{2} - 7 \, x + 6}{x + 5}, & x > 3 \end{cases}

  3. Sketch the graph of a function g(x) that satisfies both the assumptions and conclusion of the Intermediate Value Theorem on the interval [4,6] using the intermediate output value M=3 (between g(4) and g(6)). Explain why the assumptions of the IVT are important in this context.
  1. To make f(x) continuous at x=-2, let b=1.
  2. The function h(x) has a jump discontinuity and is left-continuous at x=3.

  3. The function g(x) should be continuous on the interval [4,6]. There should be a point on the graph with the output value y=3.

1. Determine the value of b to make h(x) continuous at x=-2.

    h(x) = \begin{cases} -\frac{2 \, b x - x^{2} - 4 \, b + 2 \, x}{x + 6}, & x < -2 \\ -x + 4, & x \geq -2 \end{cases}

  2. The function g(x) is discontinuous at x=-1. Determine if g(x) is left- or right-continuous and classify the type of discontinuity present at x=-1.

    g(x) = \begin{cases} x + 7, & x < -1 \\ \frac{x^{2} + 6 \, x}{x^{2} + 6 \, x + 5}, & x \geq -1 \end{cases}

  3. Sketch the graph of a function f(x) that does not satisfy the conclusion of the Intermediate Value Theorem on the interval [0,2] using the intermediate output value M=1 (between f(0) and f(2)). Explain why, in general, the assumptions of the IVT are important.
  1. To make h(x) continuous at x=-2, let b=2.
  2. The function g(x) has a infinite discontinuity and is neither left- nor right-continuous at x=-1.

  3. The function f(x) should be discontinuous on the interval [0,2]. There should be no point on the graph with the output value y=1.
exercises.html:
1. Determine the value of \(b\) to make \(h(x)\) continuous at \(x=-2\).

    \[ h(x) = \begin{cases} -\frac{2 \, b x - x^{2} - 4 \, b + 2 \, x}{x + 6}, & x < -2 \\ -x + 4, & x \geq -2 \end{cases} \]

  2. The function \(g(x)\) is discontinuous at \(x=-1\). Determine if \(g(x)\) is left- or right-continuous and classify the type of discontinuity present at \(x=-1\).

    \[ g(x) = \begin{cases} x + 7, & x < -1 \\ \frac{x^{2} + 6 \, x}{x^{2} + 6 \, x + 5}, & x \geq -1 \end{cases} \]

  3. Sketch the graph of a function \(f(x)\) that does not satisfy the conclusion of the Intermediate Value Theorem on the interval \([0,2]\) using the intermediate output value \(M=1\) (between \(f(0)\) and \(f(2)\)). Explain why, in general, the assumptions of the IVT are important.

Answer:

  1. To make \(h(x)\) continuous at \(x=-2\), let \(b=2\).
  2. The function \(g(x)\) has a infinite discontinuity and is neither left- nor right-continuous at \(x=-1\).

  3. The function \(f(x)\) should be discontinuous on the interval \([0,2]\). There should be no point on the graph with the output value \(y=1\).

exercises.pretext:
1. Determine the value of b to make h(x) continuous at x=-1.

    h(x) = \begin{cases} b x - \frac{4}{5}, & x \leq -1 \\ -x^{2} + x + 3, & x > -1 \end{cases}

  2. The function g(x) is discontinuous at x=-3. Determine if g(x) is left- or right-continuous and classify the type of discontinuity present at x=-3.

    g(x) = \begin{cases} 2 \, x + 9, & x \leq -3 \\ \frac{x^{2} + 6 \, x}{x^{2} + 11 \, x + 24}, & x > -3 \end{cases}

  3. Sketch the graph of a function f(x) that does not satisfy the conclusion of the Intermediate Value Theorem on the interval [0,3] using the intermediate output value M=4 (between f(0) and f(3)). Explain why, in general, the assumptions of the IVT are important.
  1. To make h(x) continuous at x=-1, let b=-\frac{9}{5}.
  2. The function g(x) has a infinite discontinuity and is left-continuous at x=-3.

  3. The function f(x) should be discontinuous on the interval [0,3]. There should be no point on the graph with the output value y=4.
exercises.html:
1. Determine the value of \(b\) to make \(h(x)\) continuous at \(x=-1\).

    \[ h(x) = \begin{cases} b x - \frac{4}{5}, & x \leq -1 \\ -x^{2} + x + 3, & x > -1 \end{cases} \]

  2. The function \(g(x)\) is discontinuous at \(x=-3\). Determine if \(g(x)\) is left- or right-continuous and classify the type of discontinuity present at \(x=-3\).

    \[ g(x) = \begin{cases} 2 \, x + 9, & x \leq -3 \\ \frac{x^{2} + 6 \, x}{x^{2} + 11 \, x + 24}, & x > -3 \end{cases} \]

  3. Sketch the graph of a function \(f(x)\) that does not satisfy the conclusion of the Intermediate Value Theorem on the interval \([0,3]\) using the intermediate output value \(M=4\) (between \(f(0)\) and \(f(3)\)). Explain why, in general, the assumptions of the IVT are important.

Answer:

  1. To make \(h(x)\) continuous at \(x=-1\), let \(b=-\frac{9}{5}\).
  2. The function \(g(x)\) has a infinite discontinuity and is left-continuous at \(x=-3\).

  3. The function \(f(x)\) should be discontinuous on the interval \([0,3]\). There should be no point on the graph with the output value \(y=4\).

exercises.pretext:
1. Determine the value of b to make f(x) continuous at x=3.

    f(x) = \begin{cases} b x + \frac{5}{2}, & x \leq 3 \\ x^{2} - 6 \, x + 8, & x > 3 \end{cases}

  2. The function h(x) is discontinuous at x=2. Determine if h(x) is left- or right-continuous and classify the type of discontinuity present at x=2.

    h(x) = \begin{cases} 4 \, x - 8, & x < 2 \\ \frac{x^{2} - 4 \, x + 4}{x^{2} - 5 \, x + 6}, & x \geq 2 \end{cases}

  3. Sketch the graph of a function g(x) that does not satisfy the conclusion of the Intermediate Value Theorem on the interval [5,7] using the intermediate output value M=-5 (between g(5) and g(7)). Explain why, in general, the assumptions of the IVT are important.
  1. To make f(x) continuous at x=3, let b=-\frac{7}{6}.
  2. The function h(x) has a removable discontinuity and is neither left- nor right-continuous at x=2.

  3. The function g(x) should be discontinuous on the interval [5,7]. There should be no point on the graph with the output value y=-5.
exercises.html:
1. Determine the value of \(b\) to make \(f(x)\) continuous at \(x=3\).

    \[ f(x) = \begin{cases} b x + \frac{5}{2}, & x \leq 3 \\ x^{2} - 6 \, x + 8, & x > 3 \end{cases} \]

  2. The function \(h(x)\) is discontinuous at \(x=2\). Determine if \(h(x)\) is left- or right-continuous and classify the type of discontinuity present at \(x=2\).

    \[ h(x) = \begin{cases} 4 \, x - 8, & x < 2 \\ \frac{x^{2} - 4 \, x + 4}{x^{2} - 5 \, x + 6}, & x \geq 2 \end{cases} \]

  3. Sketch the graph of a function \(g(x)\) that does not satisfy the conclusion of the Intermediate Value Theorem on the interval \([5,7]\) using the intermediate output value \(M=-5\) (between \(g(5)\) and \(g(7)\)). Explain why, in general, the assumptions of the IVT are important.

Answer:

  1. To make \(f(x)\) continuous at \(x=3\), let \(b=-\frac{7}{6}\).
  2. The function \(h(x)\) has a removable discontinuity and is neither left- nor right-continuous at \(x=2\).

  3. The function \(g(x)\) should be discontinuous on the interval \([5,7]\). There should be no point on the graph with the output value \(y=-5\).

exercises.pretext:
1. Determine the value of b to make f(x) continuous at x=-3.

    f(x) = \begin{cases} b x^{2} - 2 \, x - \frac{7}{3}, & x < -3 \\ x + 9, & x \geq -3 \end{cases}

  2. The function g(x) is discontinuous at x=4. Determine if g(x) is left- or right-continuous and classify the type of discontinuity present at x=4.

    g(x) = \begin{cases} -\frac{3}{2} \, x + 5, & x < 4 \\ \frac{x^{2} - 7 \, x + 12}{x^{2} - 9 \, x + 20}, & x \geq 4 \end{cases}

  3. Sketch the graph of a function h(x) that satisfies both the assumptions and conclusion of the Intermediate Value Theorem on the interval [4,7] using the intermediate output value M=5 (between h(4) and h(7)). Explain why the assumptions of the IVT are important in this context.
  1. To make f(x) continuous at x=-3, let b=\frac{7}{27}.
  2. The function g(x) has a removable discontinuity and is neither left- nor right-continuous at x=4.

  3. The function h(x) should be continuous on the interval [4,7]. There should be a point on the graph with the output value y=5.

1. Determine the value of \(b\) to make \(f(x)\) continuous at \(x=-3\).

    \[ f(x) = \begin{cases} b x^{2} - 2 \, x - \frac{7}{3}, & x < -3 \\ x + 9, & x \geq -3 \end{cases} \]

  3. Sketch the graph of a function \(h(x)\) that satisfies both the assumptions and conclusion of the Intermediate Value Theorem on the interval \([4,7]\) using the intermediate output value \(M=5\) (between \(h(4)\) and \(h(7)\)). Explain why the assumptions of the IVT are important in this context.

Answer:

  1. To make \(f(x)\) continuous at \(x=-3\), let \(b=\frac{7}{27}\).
  2. The function \(g(x)\) has a removable discontinuity and is neither left- nor right-continuous at \(x=4\).

  3. The function \(h(x)\) should be continuous on the interval \([4,7]\). There should be a point on the graph with the output value \(y=5\).

outcomes.title: Algebraic Approach to Limits
outcomes.description: Implement and identify basic limit laws. Evaluate limits, both finite and infinite, using various techniques including factoring, rationalizing terms, combining terms, and canceling common factors. Identify indeterminate forms and the techniques used to resolve them. Determine vertical asymptotes of a function using limits.

exercises.pretext:
Determine the value of each limit. If a two-sided limit does not exist, determine each one-sided limit. If a limit is infinite, state whether it is positive or negative infinity and describe the associated function behavior.

  1. \lim_{ x\to5 }\frac{{\left(x + 6\right)}^{4} {\left(x + 2\right)}}{{\left(x + 4\right)}^{4} {\left(x - 5\right)}^{3}}
  2. \lim_{ h\to2 }\frac{\sqrt{h + 2} - 2}{h - 2}
  3. \lim_{ x\to-1 }\frac{x^{2} - 8 \, x + 15}{x^{2} + 2 \, x - 24}
  4. \lim_{ y\to-4 }\frac{y^{2} + y - 12}{y^{2} - 2 \, y - 24}

  1. The limit does not exist.

    • \lim_{ x\to5^- }\frac{{\left(x + 6\right)}^{4} {\left(x + 2\right)}}{{\left(x + 4\right)}^{4} {\left(x - 5\right)}^{3}} = -\infty
    • \lim_{ x\to5^+ }\frac{{\left(x + 6\right)}^{4} {\left(x + 2\right)}}{{\left(x + 4\right)}^{4} {\left(x - 5\right)}^{3}} = +\infty

    • The graph of the function f(x)=\frac{{\left(x + 6\right)}^{4} {\left(x + 2\right)}}{{\left(x + 4\right)}^{4} {\left(x - 5\right)}^{3}} has a vertical asymptote at x=5.

  2. \frac{1}{4}
  3. -\frac{24}{25}
  4. \frac{7}{10}
exercises.html:
Determine the value of each limit. If a two-sided limit does not exist, determine each one-sided limit. If a limit is infinite, state whether it is positive or negative infinity and describe the associated function behavior.

  1. \[\lim_{ x\to5 }\frac{{\left(x + 6\right)}^{4} {\left(x + 2\right)}}{{\left(x + 4\right)}^{4} {\left(x - 5\right)}^{3}}\]

  2. \[\lim_{ h\to2 }\frac{\sqrt{h + 2} - 2}{h - 2}\]

  3. \[\lim_{ x\to-1 }\frac{x^{2} - 8 \, x + 15}{x^{2} + 2 \, x - 24}\]

  4. \[\lim_{ y\to-4 }\frac{y^{2} + y - 12}{y^{2} - 2 \, y - 24}\]

Answer:

  1. The limit does not exist.

    • \[\lim_{ x\to5^- }\frac{{\left(x + 6\right)}^{4} {\left(x + 2\right)}}{{\left(x + 4\right)}^{4} {\left(x - 5\right)}^{3}} = -\infty\]

    • \[\lim_{ x\to5^+ }\frac{{\left(x + 6\right)}^{4} {\left(x + 2\right)}}{{\left(x + 4\right)}^{4} {\left(x - 5\right)}^{3}} = +\infty\]

    • The graph of the function \(f(x)=\frac{{\left(x + 6\right)}^{4} {\left(x + 2\right)}}{{\left(x + 4\right)}^{4} {\left(x - 5\right)}^{3}}\) has a vertical asymptote at \(x=5\).

  2. \(\frac{1}{4}\)
  3. \(-\frac{24}{25}\)
  4. \(\frac{7}{10}\)

exercises.pretext:
Determine the value of each limit. If a two-sided limit does not exist, determine each one-sided limit. If a limit is infinite, state whether it is positive or negative infinity and describe the associated function behavior.

  1. \lim_{ x\to3 }\frac{x - 3}{\sqrt{x + 22} - 5}
  2. \lim_{ x\to-6 }\frac{x^{2} - 16}{x^{2} - 3 \, x + 2}
  3. \lim_{ t\to4 }\frac{t^{2} - 5 \, t + 4}{t^{2} + t - 20}
  4. \lim_{ y\to2 }\frac{y^{2} + 3 \, y + 2}{y^{2} - 7 \, y + 10}
  1. 10
  2. \frac{5}{14}
  3. \frac{1}{3}

  4. The limit does not exist.

    • \lim_{ y\to2^- }\frac{y^{2} + 3 \, y + 2}{y^{2} - 7 \, y + 10} = +\infty
    • \lim_{ y\to2^+ }\frac{y^{2} + 3 \, y + 2}{y^{2} - 7 \, y + 10} = -\infty

    • The graph of the function f(y)=\frac{y^{2} + 3 \, y + 2}{y^{2} - 7 \, y + 10} has a vertical asymptote at y=2.
exercises.html:
Determine the value of each limit. If a two-sided limit does not exist, determine each one-sided limit. If a limit is infinite, state whether it is positive or negative infinity and describe the associated function behavior.

  1. \[\lim_{ x\to3 }\frac{x - 3}{\sqrt{x + 22} - 5}\]

  2. \[\lim_{ x\to-6 }\frac{x^{2} - 16}{x^{2} - 3 \, x + 2}\]

  3. \[\lim_{ t\to4 }\frac{t^{2} - 5 \, t + 4}{t^{2} + t - 20}\]

  4. \[\lim_{ y\to2 }\frac{y^{2} + 3 \, y + 2}{y^{2} - 7 \, y + 10}\]

Answer:

  1. \(10\)
  2. \(\frac{5}{14}\)
  3. \(\frac{1}{3}\)

  4. The limit does not exist.

    • \[\lim_{ y\to2^- }\frac{y^{2} + 3 \, y + 2}{y^{2} - 7 \, y + 10} = +\infty\]

    • \[\lim_{ y\to2^+ }\frac{y^{2} + 3 \, y + 2}{y^{2} - 7 \, y + 10} = -\infty\]

    • The graph of the function \(f(y)=\frac{y^{2} + 3 \, y + 2}{y^{2} - 7 \, y + 10}\) has a vertical asymptote at \(y=2\).

exercises.pretext:
Determine the value of each limit. If a two-sided limit does not exist, determine each one-sided limit. If a limit is infinite, state whether it is positive or negative infinity and describe the associated function behavior.

  1. \lim_{ y\to5 }\frac{y^{2} + 9 \, y + 20}{y^{2} + y - 2}
  2. \lim_{ t\to1 }\frac{{\left(t - 4\right)}^{4} {\left(t - 6\right)}^{4}}{{\left(t + 4\right)} {\left(t - 1\right)}}
  3. \lim_{ y\to4 }\frac{4}{y - 4} - \frac{1}{\sqrt{y} - 2}
  4. \lim_{ t\to-2 }\frac{t^{2} - 3 \, t - 10}{t^{2} + 3 \, t + 2}
  1. \frac{45}{14}

  2. The limit does not exist.

    • \lim_{ t\to1^- }\frac{{\left(t - 4\right)}^{4} {\left(t - 6\right)}^{4}}{{\left(t + 4\right)} {\left(t - 1\right)}} = -\infty
    • \lim_{ t\to1^+ }\frac{{\left(t - 4\right)}^{4} {\left(t - 6\right)}^{4}}{{\left(t + 4\right)} {\left(t - 1\right)}} = +\infty

    • The graph of the function f(t)=\frac{{\left(t - 4\right)}^{4} {\left(t - 6\right)}^{4}}{{\left(t + 4\right)} {\left(t - 1\right)}} has a vertical asymptote at t=1.

  3. -\frac{1}{4}
  4. 7
exercises.html:
Determine the value of each limit. If a two-sided limit does not exist, determine each one-sided limit. If a limit is infinite, state whether it is positive or negative infinity and describe the associated function behavior.

  1. \[\lim_{ y\to5 }\frac{y^{2} + 9 \, y + 20}{y^{2} + y - 2}\]

  2. \[\lim_{ t\to1 }\frac{{\left(t - 4\right)}^{4} {\left(t - 6\right)}^{4}}{{\left(t + 4\right)} {\left(t - 1\right)}}\]

  3. \[\lim_{ y\to4 }\frac{4}{y - 4} - \frac{1}{\sqrt{y} - 2}\]

  4. \[\lim_{ t\to-2 }\frac{t^{2} - 3 \, t - 10}{t^{2} + 3 \, t + 2}\]

Answer:

  1. \(\frac{45}{14}\)

  2. The limit does not exist.

    • \[\lim_{ t\to1^- }\frac{{\left(t - 4\right)}^{4} {\left(t - 6\right)}^{4}}{{\left(t + 4\right)} {\left(t - 1\right)}} = -\infty\]

    • \[\lim_{ t\to1^+ }\frac{{\left(t - 4\right)}^{4} {\left(t - 6\right)}^{4}}{{\left(t + 4\right)} {\left(t - 1\right)}} = +\infty\]

    • The graph of the function \(f(t)=\frac{{\left(t - 4\right)}^{4} {\left(t - 6\right)}^{4}}{{\left(t + 4\right)} {\left(t - 1\right)}}\) has a vertical asymptote at \(t=1\).

  3. \(-\frac{1}{4}\)
  4. \(7\)

exercises.pretext:
Determine the value of each limit. If a two-sided limit does not exist, determine each one-sided limit. If a limit is infinite, state whether it is positive or negative infinity and describe the associated function behavior.

  1. \lim_{ h\to-2 }\frac{5 \, {\left(h + 2\right)}}{\frac{5}{h - 3} + 1}
  2. \lim_{ h\to-5 }\frac{h^{2} + 8 \, h + 15}{h^{2} + h - 20}
  3. \lim_{ y\to-5 }\frac{y^{2} - 7 \, y + 10}{y^{2} - 5 \, y - 6}
  4. \lim_{ t\to-3 }\frac{t^{2} - 4 \, t - 5}{t^{2} + 5 \, t + 6}
  1. -25
  2. \frac{2}{9}
  3. \frac{35}{22}

  4. The limit does not exist.

    • \lim_{ t\to-3^- }\frac{t^{2} - 4 \, t - 5}{t^{2} + 5 \, t + 6} = +\infty
    • \lim_{ t\to-3^+ }\frac{t^{2} - 4 \, t - 5}{t^{2} + 5 \, t + 6} = -\infty

    • The graph of the function f(t)=\frac{t^{2} - 4 \, t - 5}{t^{2} + 5 \, t + 6} has a vertical asymptote at t=-3.

Determine the value of each limit. If a two-sided limit does not exist, determine each one-sided limit. If a limit is infinite, state whether it is positive or negative infinity and describe the associated function behavior.

Answer:

  4. The limit does not exist.

exercises.pretext:
Determine the value of each limit. If a two-sided limit does not exist, determine each one-sided limit. If a limit is infinite, state whether it is positive or negative infinity and describe the associated function behavior.

  4. \lim_{ t\to2 }\frac{t^{2} - t - 6}{t^{2} - 5 \, t + 6}

  2. \frac{2}{3}
  3. \frac{8}{99}

  4. The limit does not exist.

    • \lim_{ t\to2^- }\frac{t^{2} - t - 6}{t^{2} - 5 \, t + 6} = -\infty

exercises.html:
Determine the value of each limit. If a two-sided limit does not exist, determine each one-sided limit. If a limit is infinite, state whether it is positive or negative infinity and describe the associated function behavior.

  1. \[\lim_{ h\to2 }\frac{h^{2} - 4}{h^{2} + h - 6}\]

  2. \[\lim_{ y\to7 }\frac{\sqrt{y - 3} - 2}{y - 7}\]

  3. \[\lim_{ t\to6 }\frac{t^{2} - t - 6}{t^{2} - 1}\]

  4. \[\lim_{ h\to3 }\frac{{\left(h + 5\right)} {\left(h - 6\right)}}{{\left(h - 1\right)}^{2} {\left(h - 3\right)}^{2}}\]

Answer:

  1. \(\frac{4}{5}\)
  2. \(\frac{1}{4}\)
  3. \(\frac{24}{35}\)

  4. The limit does not exist.

    • \[\lim_{ h\to3^- }\frac{{\left(h + 5\right)} {\left(h - 6\right)}}{{\left(h - 1\right)}^{2} {\left(h - 3\right)}^{2}} = -\infty\]

    • \[\lim_{ h\to3^+ }\frac{{\left(h + 5\right)} {\left(h - 6\right)}}{{\left(h - 1\right)}^{2} {\left(h - 3\right)}^{2}} = -\infty\]

    • The graph of the function \(f(h)=\frac{{\left(h + 5\right)} {\left(h - 6\right)}}{{\left(h - 1\right)}^{2} {\left(h - 3\right)}^{2}}\) has a vertical asymptote at \(h=3\).

exercises.pretext:
Determine the value of each limit. If a two-sided limit does not exist, determine each one-sided limit. If a limit is infinite, state whether it is positive or negative infinity and describe the associated function behavior.

  1. \lim_{ t\to-5 }\frac{t^{2} + 6 \, t + 5}{t^{2} + 3 \, t - 10}
  2. \lim_{ y\to4 }\frac{y^{2} - 8 \, y + 12}{y^{2} + 2 \, y - 15}
  3. \lim_{ y\to8 }\frac{y - 8}{\sqrt{y + 1} - 3}
  4. \lim_{ y\to5 }\frac{y^{2} + 3 \, y + 2}{y^{2} - 25}
  1. \frac{4}{7}
  2. -\frac{4}{9}
  3. 6

  4. The limit does not exist.

    • \lim_{ y\to5^- }\frac{y^{2} + 3 \, y + 2}{y^{2} - 25} = -\infty
    • \lim_{ y\to5^+ }\frac{y^{2} + 3 \, y + 2}{y^{2} - 25} = +\infty

    • The graph of the function f(y)=\frac{y^{2} + 3 \, y + 2}{y^{2} - 25} has a vertical asymptote at y=5.
exercises.html:
Determine the value of each limit. If a two-sided limit does not exist, determine each one-sided limit. If a limit is infinite, state whether it is positive or negative infinity and describe the associated function behavior.

  1. \[\lim_{ t\to-5 }\frac{t^{2} + 6 \, t + 5}{t^{2} + 3 \, t - 10}\]

  2. \[\lim_{ y\to4 }\frac{y^{2} - 8 \, y + 12}{y^{2} + 2 \, y - 15}\]

  3. \[\lim_{ y\to8 }\frac{y - 8}{\sqrt{y + 1} - 3}\]

  4. \[\lim_{ y\to5 }\frac{y^{2} + 3 \, y + 2}{y^{2} - 25}\]

Answer:

  1. \(\frac{4}{7}\)
  2. \(-\frac{4}{9}\)
  3. \(6\)

  4. The limit does not exist.

    • \[\lim_{ y\to5^- }\frac{y^{2} + 3 \, y + 2}{y^{2} - 25} = -\infty\]

    • \[\lim_{ y\to5^+ }\frac{y^{2} + 3 \, y + 2}{y^{2} - 25} = +\infty\]

    • The graph of the function \(f(y)=\frac{y^{2} + 3 \, y + 2}{y^{2} - 25}\) has a vertical asymptote at \(y=5\).

  1. \lim_{ t\to4 }\frac{t^{2} - t - 12}{t^{2} + t - 20}

  1. \frac{7}{9}

  2. The limit does not exist.

    • \lim_{ t\to6^- }\frac{{\left(t - 1\right)} {\left(t - 5\right)}^{2}}{{\left(t + 6\right)}^{2} {\left(t - 6\right)}} = -\infty

  4. -1

  3. \[\lim_{ t\to-5 }\frac{t^{2} + 3 \, t - 4}{t^{2} + 5 \, t + 6}\]

  4. \[\lim_{ h\to-6 }\frac{h + 6}{\frac{1}{h + 7} - 1}\]

  2. The limit does not exist.

  4. \(-1\)

outcomes.title: Trigonometric Limits and the Squeeze Theorem
outcomes.description: Evaluate limits involving trigonometric expressions using the squeeze theorem or the important the trigonometric limits $\lim_{\theta\to 0} \frac{\sin(\theta)}{\theta}=1$, $\lim_{\theta\to 0} \frac{\theta}{\sin(\theta)}=1$, and $\lim_{\theta\to 0} \frac{1-\cos(\theta)}{\theta}=0$.

exercises.pretext:
Determine the value of each limit. Explain your reasoning clearly.

  1. \lim_{ x \to 0^{ + } }\sqrt{x} \cos\left(-\frac{5}{x^{3}}\right)
  2. \lim_{ \theta \to 0^{ } }\frac{\tan\left(-3 \, \theta\right)}{\theta \cos\left(2 \, \theta\right)}
  1. 0
  2. -3

  1. \lim_{ \theta \to 0^{ } }\theta^{6} \sin\left(-\frac{4}{\theta^{4}}\right)
  2. \lim_{ x \to 0^{ } }-\frac{5 \, {\left(\cos\left(x\right) - 1\right)}}{2 \, x \cos\left(x\right)}
  1. 0
  2. 0
exercises.html:
Determine the value of each limit. Explain your reasoning clearly.

  1. \[\lim_{ \theta \to 0^{ } }\theta^{6} \sin\left(-\frac{4}{\theta^{4}}\right)\]

  2. \[\lim_{ x \to 0^{ } }-\frac{5 \, {\left(\cos\left(x\right) - 1\right)}}{2 \, x \cos\left(x\right)}\]

Answer:

  1. \(0\)
  2. \(0\)

outcomes.title: Limits at Infinity
outcomes.description: Evaluate limits at infinity. Evaluate limits at infinity with quotients involving roots by factoring out (or dividing out) the growing terms. Determine the horizontal asymptotes of a function using limits.

exercises.pretext:
1. Determine the value of the given limit. If the limit is infinite, state whether it is positive or negative infinity.

    \lim_{x\to-\infty } \frac{3 \, x^{2} - 5 \, \sqrt{x^{6}}}{7 \, x^{3} + 6 \, x^{2} - 3 \, x}

  2. Determine all horizontal asympototes of the given function. If the function has no horizontal asymptotes, describe the end behavior of the function. Use limits to justify your answer.

    f(x) = -\frac{4 \, x^{3} - x^{2} - 2 \, x}{6 \, x^{3} + 7 \, x}
  1. \frac{5}{7}

  2. Horizontal asymptotes of f(x):

    • y = -\frac{2}{3}.
exercises.html:
1. Determine the value of the given limit. If the limit is infinite, state whether it is positive or negative infinity.

    \[\lim_{x\to-\infty } \frac{3 \, x^{2} - 5 \, \sqrt{x^{6}}}{7 \, x^{3} + 6 \, x^{2} - 3 \, x}\]

  2. Determine all horizontal asympototes of the given function. If the function has no horizontal asymptotes, describe the end behavior of the function. Use limits to justify your answer.

    \[f(x) = -\frac{4 \, x^{3} - x^{2} - 2 \, x}{6 \, x^{3} + 7 \, x}\]

Answer:

  1. \(\frac{5}{7}\)

  2. Horizontal asymptotes of \(f(x)\):

    • \(y = -\frac{2}{3}\).

exercises.pretext:
1. Determine the value of the given limit. If the limit is infinite, state whether it is positive or negative infinity.

    \lim_{x\to+\infty } \frac{x^{6} - 8 \, x^{4} + 8 \, x^{2}}{6 \, x^{5} + 7 \, x^{4} + 4 \, x^{3}}

  2. Determine all horizontal asympototes of the given function. If the function has no horizontal asymptotes, describe the end behavior of the function. Use limits to justify your answer.

    f(x) = \frac{3 \, x^{3} + 6 \, x^{2} + 8 \, x}{4 \, x - 7 \, \sqrt{x^{6}}}
  1. +\infty

  2. Horizontal asymptotes of f(x):

    • y = \frac{3}{7}.
    • y = -\frac{3}{7}.
exercises.html:

    \[\lim_{x\to+\infty } \frac{x^{6} - 8 \, x^{4} + 8 \, x^{2}}{6 \, x^{5} + 7 \, x^{4} + 4 \, x^{3}}\]

  2. Determine all horizontal asympototes of the given function. If the function has no horizontal asymptotes, describe the end behavior of the function. Use limits to justify your answer.

    \[f(x) = \frac{3 \, x^{3} + 6 \, x^{2} + 8 \, x}{4 \, x - 7 \, \sqrt{x^{6}}}\]

Answer:

  1. \(+\infty\)

  2. Horizontal asymptotes of \(f(x)\):

    • \(y = \frac{3}{7}\).
    • \(y = -\frac{3}{7}\).

exercises.pretext:
1. Determine the value of the given limit. If the limit is infinite, state whether it is positive or negative infinity.

    \lim_{x\to+\infty } -\frac{2 \, {\left(3 \, x^{3} + 2 \, x\right)}}{x^{4} - 7 \, x^{2} - 4 \, x}

  2. Determine all horizontal asympototes of the given function. If the function has no horizontal asymptotes, describe the end behavior of the function. Use limits to justify your answer.

    f(x) = -\frac{\sqrt{x^{10}} + 3}{2 \, {\left(3 \, x^{4} + x^{2}\right)}}
  1. 0

  2. The function f(x) has no horizontal asymptotes. The end behavior of f(x) is as follows:

    • \lim_{x\to-\infty}-\frac{\sqrt{x^{10}} + 3}{2 \, {\left(3 \, x^{4} + x^{2}\right)}} = -\infty.
    • \lim_{x\to+\infty}-\frac{\sqrt{x^{10}} + 3}{2 \, {\left(3 \, x^{4} + x^{2}\right)}} = -\infty.

Answer:

  1. \(0\)

  2. The function \(f(x)\) has no horizontal asymptotes. The end behavior of \(f(x)\) is as follows:

    • \(\lim_{x\to-\infty}-\frac{\sqrt{x^{10}} + 3}{2 \, {\left(3 \, x^{4} + x^{2}\right)}} = -\infty\).
    • \(\lim_{x\to+\infty}-\frac{\sqrt{x^{10}} + 3}{2 \, {\left(3 \, x^{4} + x^{2}\right)}} = -\infty\).

exercises.html:
1. Determine the value of the given limit. If the limit is infinite, state whether it is positive or negative infinity.

    \[\lim_{x\to-\infty } \frac{9 \, x^{6} - 6 \, x^{3} - 1}{6 \, x^{6} - 7 \, x^{2}}\]

  2. Determine all horizontal asympototes of the given function. If the function has no horizontal asymptotes, describe the end behavior of the function. Use limits to justify your answer.

    \[f(x) = \frac{7 \, \sqrt{x^{8} - 7 \, x^{3}}}{2 \, {\left(4 \, x^{4} + x\right)}}\]

Answer:

  1. \(\frac{3}{2}\)

  2. Horizontal asymptotes of \(f(x)\):

    • \(y = \frac{7}{8}\).

exercises.pretext:

  2. Determine all horizontal asympototes of the given function. If the function has no horizontal asymptotes, describe the end behavior of the function. Use limits to justify your answer.

    f(x) = -\frac{2 \, x^{4} + 3 \, x^{3}}{2 \, x^{3} - 3 \, \sqrt{x^{12}}}

  2. Horizontal asymptotes of f(x):

    • y = 0.
